title: How do we know what color dinosaurs were? - Len Bloch

multiple-choice.question: What was the approximate length of the microraptor dinosaur?
What was the primary source of information about the microraptor?

options.label: C
options.text: Fossils with imprints of bones and feathers

multiple-choice.question: What gives birds their diverse colorations?

options.label: B
options.text: A combination of carotenoids and melanin

options.label: D
options.text: Most feathers contain just one or two dye-like pigments

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of melanin in bird feathers?

options.label: B
options.text: It forms hollow nanostructures called melanosomes

multiple-choice.question: What is the distance between the crests of red light waves?
How do melanosomes produce color?

options.label: C
options.text: By interacting with light waves and reinforcing certain wavelengths

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the X-ray analysis of the melanosomes found in the microraptor fossil?

options.label: A
options.text: They contained minerals that would result from the decay of carotenoids

options.label: B
options.text: They contained minerals that would result from the decay of melanin

options.label: D
options.text: They contained a variety of minerals

multiple-choice.question: What was the conclusion drawn by scientists after examining the melanosomes in 20 feathers from the microraptor fossil?

options.label: A
options.text: The dinosaur had a variety of colors

options.label: B
options.text: The dinosaur was one solid color

multiple-choice.question: What was the color of the microraptor's feathers, as determined by scientists?
What has been discovered about many dinosaurs, including velociraptor, through the study of fossils with well-preserved melanosomes?

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the shape of a snowflake?

options.label: A
options.text: When liquid water freezes into a solid

options.label: B
options.text: When water vapor turns straight into ice

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What type of bonds are formed between the atoms in a water molecule?
Why do the electron pairs in a water molecule stay far away from each other?
What is the angle between the hydrogens in a water molecule?
What type of bond is formed between two water molecules?
Why do snowflakes retain a hexagonal shape as they grow?

options.label: A
options.text: Due to the angle between hydrogens and oxygen within each molecule

options.label: C
options.text: Due to the temperature and humidity

multiple-choice.question: What affects the shape of a snowflake as it falls?

options.label: C
options.text: Atmospheric conditions, such as humidity and temperature

multiple-choice.question: Why is completely dry snow difficult to ski on?

options.label: C
options.text: Because there's too much friction between the jagged snowflakes and the ski surface

title: Forget shopping. Soon you'll download your new clothes - Danit Peleg

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's problem when she was invited to an important event and wanted to wear something special and new?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: She had no money to buy new clothes.

options.label: C
options.text: She couldn't find anything to wear in her suitcase.

options.label: D
options.text: She didn't know how to design clothes.

options.label: A
options.text: She bought it from a store.

options.label: B
options.text: She borrowed it from a friend.

options.label: C
options.text: She designed it on her computer and printed it using a 3D printer.

options.label: A
options.text: To create a fashion collection using traditional materials.

options.label: B
options.text: To create a fashion collection using 3D printing.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: To create a fashion accessory using 3D printing.

options.text: They were made from hard plastics and were very breakable.

multiple-choice.question: What inspired the speaker to try printing clothes from home?

options.label: A
options.text: A friend gave her a 3D printed necklace.

options.label: B
options.text: She saw a 3D printed dress in a store.

options.label: C
options.text: She read about 3D printing in a book.

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's vision for the future of fashion?

options.label: A
options.text: That clothes will be made from traditional materials.

options.label: B
options.text: That clothes will be made using only 3D printing.

options.label: C
options.text: That materials will evolve and clothes will be personalized and digital.

multiple-choice.question: In which millennium BCE did Mesopotamian kings record and interpret their dreams on wax tablets?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A collection of images from our daily conscious lives with symbolic meanings related to our conscious wishes

options.label: D
options.text: A collection of images from our daily unconscious lives with symbolic meanings related to the fulfillment of our conscious wishes

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Dreaming significantly increased performance, with subjects performing up to ten times better

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The process of dreaming to rehearse primitive instincts

options.label: C
options.text: The process of dreaming to heal from traumatic experiences

options.label: D
options.text: The process of dreaming to consolidate memories

title: The ethical dilemma of self-driving cars - Patrick Lin

multiple-choice.question: What is the central dilemma presented in the thought experiment involving a self-driving car?

options.label: A
options.text: Whether to prioritize the safety of the car's occupants or the safety of other road users

options.label: B
options.text: Whether to prioritize fuel efficiency or speed

options.label: C
options.text: Whether to prioritize navigation or entertainment

options.label: D
options.text: Whether to prioritize vehicle maintenance or design aesthetics

multiple-choice.question: What is the predicted outcome of implementing self-driving cars on the road?

options.label: A
options.text: An increase in traffic accidents and fatalities

options.label: B
options.text: A dramatic reduction in traffic accidents and fatalities

options.label: C
options.text: No change in traffic accidents and fatalities

options.label: D
options.text: A slight increase in traffic accidents, but a decrease in fatalities

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential benefit of self-driving cars mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: C
options.text: Increased unproductive and stressful driving time

multiple-choice.question: Who may be responsible for determining the outcomes of accidents involving self-driving cars?
What is the problem with offering general decision-making principles, such as "minimize harm", in the context of self-driving cars?

options.label: A
options.text: It leads to morally clear decisions

options.label: B
options.text: It leads to morally murky decisions

options.label: C
options.text: It has no impact on decision-making

options.label: D
options.text: It is not relevant to self-driving cars

multiple-choice.question: In the scenario involving two motorcyclists, one wearing a helmet and one not, what is the dilemma presented?

options.label: A
options.text: Whether to prioritize the safety of the motorcyclist wearing a helmet or the motorcyclist not wearing a helmet

options.label: B
options.text: Whether to prioritize the safety of the car's occupants or the motorcyclists

options.label: C
options.text: Whether to prioritize the safety of the motorcyclist wearing a helmet or the car's occupants

options.label: D
options.text: Whether to prioritize the safety of the motorcyclist not wearing a helmet or the car's occupants

multiple-choice.question: What is the concern with a self-driving car's algorithm systematically favoring or discriminating against certain types of objects to crash into?

options.label: A
options.text: It may lead to increased safety for the car's occupants

options.label: B
options.text: It may lead to decreased safety for other road users

options.label: C
options.text: It may lead to negative consequences for the owners of the target vehicles through no fault of their own

options.label: D
options.text: It may lead to increased efficiency in traffic flow

multiple-choice.question: What is the novel ethical dilemma presented by the possibility of self-driving cars analyzing and factoring in the passengers of the cars and the particulars of their lives?

options.label: A
options.text: Whether to prioritize the safety of the car's occupants or other road users

options.label: B
options.text: Whether to prioritize the safety of passengers based on their personal characteristics or circumstances

options.label: C
options.text: Whether to prioritize the safety of pedestrians or other road users

options.label: D
options.text: Whether to prioritize the safety of the car's occupants or the environment

multiple-choice.question: Who should be making the decisions regarding the ethics of self-driving cars?

options.label: D
options.text: A combination of programmers, companies, and governments

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of thought experiments like the ones presented in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To predict exactly how reality will play out

options.label: B
options.text: To isolate and stress test our intuitions on ethics

options.label: C
options.text: To determine the most efficient solution to a problem

options.label: D
options.text: To prioritize the safety of the car's occupants above all else

title: Would you opt for a life with no pain? - Hayley Levitt and Bethany Rickwald

multiple-choice.question: What is the main question posed by philosopher Robert Nozick's thought experiment, the Experience Machine?

options.label: A
options.text: Would you choose to live a life of ultimate pain?

options.label: B
options.text: Would you choose to live a life of ultimate pleasure?

options.label: C
options.text: Would you choose to live a life of both pleasure and pain?

options.label: D
options.text: Would you choose to live a life of neither pleasure nor pain?

multiple-choice.question: What is the catch of signing up for the Experience Machine?

options.label: A
options.text: You have to temporarily leave reality behind.

options.label: B
options.text: You have to permanently leave reality behind.

options.label: C
options.text: You have to stay in reality forever.

options.label: D
options.text: You have to alternate between reality and the machine.

multiple-choice.question: What is the philosophical notion that the Experience Machine is designed to refute?
According to hedonists, what is the most important thing in life?
What is the scenario presented in the Experience Machine thought experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: A life of ultimate pain with no pleasure

options.label: B
options.text: A life of ultimate pleasure with no pain

options.label: C
options.text: A life of both pleasure and pain

options.label: D
options.text: A life of neither pleasure nor pain

multiple-choice.question: Why might someone choose not to plug into the Experience Machine?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they want to experience pain

options.label: B
options.text: Because they want to experience reality

options.label: C
options.text: Because they want to experience nothing

options.label: D
options.text: Because they want to experience only pleasure

multiple-choice.question: What is the example given to illustrate the value of knowing the truth?

options.label: A
options.text: A person who is unaware of their partner's infidelity

options.label: B
options.text: A person who is aware of their partner's infidelity

options.label: C
options.text: A person who is in a loving, committed relationship

options.label: D
options.text: A person who is not in a relationship

multiple-choice.question: What are some things that might have greater intrinsic value than pleasure?

options.label: A
options.text: Truth, knowledge, and authentic connection with others

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the Experience Machine thought experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: To prove that hedonism is the best philosophy

options.label: B
options.text: To refute the idea of hedonism

options.label: C
options.text: To show that reality has no value

options.label: D
options.text: To demonstrate that pleasure is the only good

multiple-choice.question: What is the main conclusion of the Experience Machine thought experiment?

options.label: B
options.text: That pleasure is the only good

options.label: C
options.text: That there may be things with greater intrinsic value than pleasure

options.label: D
options.text: That hedonism is the best philosophy

title: How to write descriptively - Nalo Hopkinson

multiple-choice.question: Why do people read fiction?

options.label: B
options.text: To be entertained, to think, to feel, and to escape reality

multiple-choice.question: What literary device is used in the description "Billie's legs are noodles"?

options.label: B
options.text: To create a momentary illusion that the reader is living in the world of the story

options.label: C
options.text: To provide a summary of the plot

multiple-choice.question: How does prose fiction engage the reader's senses compared to stage and screen?

options.label: B
options.text: Indirectly through static symbols on a contrasting background

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of using generic words, such as "sound," in fiction writing?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates a vivid mental image

options.label: B
options.text: It engages the reader's sense of hearing

options.label: C
options.text: It weakens the spell of the story

options.label: D
options.text: It provides a summary of the plot

multiple-choice.question: In the sentence "The world was ghost-quiet, except for the crack of sails and the burbling of water against hull," what sense is evoked by the words "quiet," "crack," and "burbling"?
Why should writers avoid using clichés in their writing?

options.label: C
options.text: Because there's very little engagement for the reader in an overused image

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of using unexpected connotations among story elements in fiction writing?

options.label: C
options.text: It sets the reader's imagination alight

options.label: D
options.text: It provides a summary of the plot

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of using metaphors, such as "ghost-quiet," in fiction writing?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a distancing layer of simile between the reader and the experience

options.label: C
options.text: To provide a summary of the plot

multiple-choice.question: What should writers use to engage the reader's senses and create a dynamic world of the senses?

options.label: A
options.text: Well-chosen words to engage sound, sight, taste, touch, smell, and movement

options.label: B
options.text: Generic words to summarize the plot

options.label: C
options.text: Clichés to create a familiar image

options.label: D
options.text: Similes to create a distancing layer

options.label: A

options.label: D

title: What makes muscles grow? - Jeffrey Siegel

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of our body weight is made up of muscles?
What happens when the brain sends a signal to motor neurons inside the arm to pull a door open?

options.label: A
options.text: The muscles contract and relax, but do not generate movement.

options.label: B
options.text: The muscles contract and relax, generating the needed movement.

options.label: C
options.text: The muscles only contract, generating the needed movement.

options.label: D
options.text: The muscles only relax, generating the needed movement.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when muscle fibers undergo stress and experience microscopic damage?

options.label: A
options.text: The injured cells release cytokines that activate the immune system to destroy the muscle tissue.

options.label: B
options.text: The injured cells release cytokines that activate the immune system to repair the injury.

options.label: C
options.text: The injured cells release hormones that activate the immune system to repair the injury.

options.label: D
options.text: The injured cells release amino acids that activate the immune system to repair the injury.

multiple-choice.question: What is the process called when muscles grow and become stronger as they adapt to progressively greater demands?
What happens to muscles if they are not continuously exposed to some resistance?

options.label: A
options.text: They will grow and become stronger.

options.label: B
options.text: They will remain the same size and strength.

options.label: C
options.text: They will shrink, a process known as muscular atrophy.

options.label: D
options.text: They will become damaged and unable to repair themselves.

multiple-choice.question: What is the most effective way to stimulate new muscle growth?

options.label: A
options.text: Exposing muscles to low workloads and minimal resistance.

options.label: B
options.text: Exposing muscles to high workloads and significant resistance.

options.label: C
options.text: Exposing muscles to moderate workloads and some resistance.

options.label: D
options.text: Exposing muscles to no workloads or resistance.

multiple-choice.question: What is necessary for muscle growth and repair, in addition to activity and exercise?

options.label: B
options.text: Proper nutrition and hormones, but not rest.

options.label: C
options.text: Proper nutrition and rest, but not hormones.

options.label: D
options.text: Hormones and rest, but not proper nutrition.

multiple-choice.question: What role does protein play in muscle growth and repair?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides the building blocks for new tissue in the form of amino acids.

options.label: B
options.text: It provides the energy needed for muscle contraction and relaxation.

options.label: C
options.text: It helps to break down muscle tissue and prevent growth.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no role in muscle growth and repair.

multiple-choice.question: When does the vital repair process of muscle growth and repair mainly occur?

options.label: B
options.text: When we're resting, especially at night while sleeping.

options.label: D
options.text: During periods of stress and anxiety.

multiple-choice.question: What is necessary for meaningful growth and development of muscles?

options.label: B
options.text: Exposing muscles to minimal resistance and workload.

options.label: C
options.text: Providing proper nutrition, hormones, and rest, but not challenging the muscles.

options.label: D
options.text: Challenging the muscles and exposing them to stress.

multiple-choice.question: What is stress described as in the transcript?

options.text: A physical response that travels throughout the entire body

options.label: D

options.text: The International Covenant on Human Rights

How many articles are listed in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights?

options.label: A
options.text: Only negative freedoms, such as freedom from torture or slavery

options.label: B
options.text: Only positive freedoms, such as freedom of movement and residence

multiple-choice.question: Why is it challenging to universally enforce human rights?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the concept of human rights is not well-developed

options.label: B
options.text: Because individual countries have different interpretations of human rights

options.label: C
options.text: Because the mechanisms to address violations are weak

options.label: D
options.text: Because human rights are not relevant in modern societies

multiple-choice.question: What is the main criticism of the universality of human rights?

options.label: A
options.text: That human rights are not applicable to all cultures and societies

options.label: B
options.text: That the development of human rights has been heavily guided by a small number of mostly Western nations

options.label: C
options.text: That human rights are not relevant in modern societies

options.label: D
options.text: That human rights are only applicable to individual rights, not collective or group rights

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of an international human rights instrument that establishes a court where member countries and their citizens can bring cases?

options.label: A
options.text: The Universal Declaration of Human Rights

options.label: B
options.text: The International Covenant on Human Rights

options.label: C
options.text: The European Convention on Human Rights

multiple-choice.question: Why is human rights law constantly evolving?

options.label: A
options.text: Because our views and definitions of what the basic human rights should be are changing

options.label: B
options.text: Because human rights are not relevant in modern societies

options.label: C
options.text: Because individual countries have different interpretations of human rights

options.label: D
options.text: Because the concept of human rights is not well-developed

title: Where does gold come from? - David Lunney

multiple-choice.question: What was the goal of medieval alchemists in their experiments?
According to the transcript, where does gold originate from?

options.label: D
options.text: Other planets in the solar system

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary element that makes up the composition of stars?

options.label: A
options.text: The star becomes a black hole

options.label: B
options.text: The star explodes, forming a supernova

options.label: C
options.text: The star cools down and becomes a white dwarf

options.label: D
options.text: The star expands into a red giant

multiple-choice.question: What is formed when subatomic protons and electrons are forced together in the core of a collapsing star?
How are heavier elements, such as gold, formed in a supernova?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Through the capture of neutrons by iron group elements

options.label: C
options.text: Through the release of electrons by iron group elements

options.label: D
options.text: Through the release of protons by iron group elements

multiple-choice.question: How is gold delivered to planets like Earth after a supernova explosion?

options.label: A
options.text: Through the expanding supernova shockwave propelling elemental debris

options.label: B
options.text: Through the collapse of the star's outer layers

options.label: C
options.text: Through the formation of black holes

options.label: D
options.text: Through the cooling of the star

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The concentration of gold in the ocean is too low

options.label: D
options.text: The ocean is too deep to extract gold

multiple-choice.question: What is a hypothetical method of producing gold, although it is not currently practical?

options.label: A
options.text: Mining other planets in the solar system

options.label: C
options.text: Using particle accelerators to mimic nuclear reactions in stars

options.label: D
options.text: Transforming lead into gold through alchemy

title: Can you solve the prisoner hat riddle? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What is the condition set by the alien overlords to spare the humans?

options.label: A
options.text: At least 5 humans guess their hat color correctly

options.label: B
options.text: At least 7 humans guess their hat color correctly

options.label: C
options.text: At least 9 humans guess their hat color correctly

options.label: D
options.text: All humans guess their hat color correctly

multiple-choice.question: What information can the person at the back of the line communicate using the words "black" or "white"?

options.label: A
options.text: The total number of black or white hats

options.label: B
options.text: The number of people wearing black hats

options.label: C
options.text: The parity (odd or even) of the number of black hats

options.label: D
options.text: The color of their own hat

multiple-choice.question: What does the person at the back of the line say if they see an odd number of black hats?
What is the purpose of the coded information conveyed by the person at the back of the line?

options.label: A
options.text: To tell the others the total number of black hats

options.label: B
options.text: To tell the others the color of their own hat

options.label: C
options.text: To allow the others to deduce their hat colors

multiple-choice.question: What happens if the person at the back of the line gets their own hat color wrong?

options.label: C
options.text: It's okay, as the group is collectively allowed one wrong answer

multiple-choice.question: How do the prisoners use the parity information to deduce their hat colors?

options.label: A
options.text: By counting the total number of black hats

options.label: B
options.text: By expecting to see an odd or even number of hats of the specified color

options.label: C
options.text: By looking at the color of the hat in front of them

multiple-choice.question: What happens if a prisoner's count of hats doesn't match the expected parity?

options.label: C
options.text: They deduce that their own hat is the specified color

multiple-choice.question: What is the probability of the first prisoner giving a wrong answer about their own hat?
What is the outcome for the humans if they successfully implement the strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: They will be eaten by the aliens

options.label: B
options.text: They will be held captive forever

options.label: D
options.text: They will be given another test

multiple-choice.question: Why do the aliens ultimately decide not to eat the humans?

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are not logical and cooperative

options.label: C
options.text: Because the humans passed the test and proved to be logical and cooperative

options.label: D
options.text: Because they found another food source

title: What "Orwellian" really means - Noah Tavlin

multiple-choice.question: Who is the British author behind the pen name George Orwell?
What is the primary theme of George Orwell's novel "1984"?

options.label: A
options.text: A utopian society with unlimited freedom

options.label: B
options.text: An oppressive society under a totalitarian government

options.label: C
options.text: A historical account of World War II

options.label: D
options.text: A romance novel set in the 19th century

multiple-choice.question: What does the term "Orwellian" often refer to, although it doesn't fully convey Orwell's message?
According to Orwell, what plays a crucial role in shaping our thoughts and opinions?
What is the name of the fictional government ministry in "1984" responsible for manufacturing historical facts and statistics?
What term describes the use of words to undermine their meaning, as seen in the deliberate irony of "1984"'s government ministries?
What is the name of the official dialect created by the regime in "1984", characterized by a limited collection of acronyms and simple concrete nouns?
According to Orwell, what is the result of the regime's control of language on the individual's thought process?

options.label: B
options.text: Complete dependence on the State's definition of reality

multiple-choice.question: In his essay "Politics and the English Language", Orwell described techniques such as using pretentious words to project authority and making atrocities sound acceptable by burying them in:
According to the transcript, what is the ultimate reason Orwell urged us to protect our language?

options.label: A
options.text: To prevent war and promote peace

options.label: D
options.text: Because our ability to think and communicate clearly is what stands between us and a world where war is peace and freedom is slavery

title: Democracy - A short introduction

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of the word "democracy"?
In ancient Athens, who was not allowed to vote?

options.label: C
options.text: Slaves, women, children, and people without land

multiple-choice.question: What document, signed in 1215, prevented the King of England from doing whatever he wanted?
What type of democracy is most common today?
What are the three branches of power in modern democracies?
What concept, developed by Jean-Jacques Rousseau, refers to the government reflecting the wishes and values of society?
What is one of the problems of democratic voting?

options.label: A
options.text: The smallest groups of people have the most power

options.label: B
options.text: The biggest groups of people always have the most power

options.label: C
options.text: The government has too much power

options.label: D
options.text: The people have too little power

options.label: B
options.text: The worst form of government except for all others

options.label: C
options.text: A form of government that is only suitable for small countries

options.label: D
options.text: A form of government that is only suitable for large countries

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the system of checks and balances in a democracy?

options.label: A
options.text: To give the government more power

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To protect the rights of the majority

options.label: D
options.text: To protect the rights of the minority

multiple-choice.question: What is a key characteristic of a functioning democracy?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The government has the power to do whatever it wants

options.label: C
options.text: The people have the power to vote for their representatives

options.label: D
options.text: The government protects the rights of all citizens, including minorities

title: When to use "me", "myself" and "I" - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What type of pronoun is "I" in a sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: I invited her but she invited me.

options.label: B
options.text: She danced around me, while he shimmied up to me.

options.label: C
options.text: I consider myself the most important pronoun at this year's party.

options.label: D
options.text: I, myself, have heard others agree.

options.label: A
options.text: English nouns have different forms for subjects and objects.

options.label: B
options.text: Latin and Russian nouns have different forms for subjects and objects.

options.label: C
options.text: English pronouns have different forms for subjects and objects.

options.label: D
options.text: Latin and Russian pronouns have the same forms for subjects and objects.

multiple-choice.question: How can you determine whether to use "I" or "me" in a complicated sentence?

options.label: B
options.text: By identifying the subject and object

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following sentences is grammatically correct?
What is the correct pronoun to use in the sentence "Please tell Jack or _______"?
When can "myself" be used as a reflexive pronoun?

options.label: A
options.text: When it's the subject of a sentence

options.label: B
options.text: When it's the object of a sentence whose subject is "I"

options.label: C
options.text: When it's the object of a preposition

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of "myself" in the sentence "I, myself, have heard others agree"?
How can you check if "myself" belongs in a sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: By ensuring that there's also a "you" in the sentence

options.label: B
options.text: By ensuring that there's also an "I" that it's reflecting or intensifying

What is the main difference between human language and animal communication, according to the transcript?

options.label: C

options.text: He began to dance on the boat.

title: How false news can spread - Noah Tavlin

multiple-choice.question: Who is the writer to whom the quote "A lie can travel halfway around the world while the truth is putting on its shoes" is usually attributed?
What is the term used to describe the phenomenon where publication A publishes misinformation, publication B reprints it, and publication A then cites B as the source for the information?
What was the claim made by a 1998 pseudoscientific paper that inspired an antivaccination movement?

options.label: A
options.text: Routine vaccination of children causes cancer

options.label: B
options.text: Routine vaccination of children causes autism

options.label: C
options.text: Routine vaccination of children causes ADHD

options.label: D
options.text: Routine vaccination of children has no health benefits

multiple-choice.question: What has been the result of some children not being vaccinated due to the antivaccination movement?

options.label: A
options.text: They have become immune to all diseases

options.label: B
options.text: They have a lower risk of contracting contagious diseases

options.label: C
options.text: They are now contracting contagious diseases that had been virtually eradicated in the United States

options.label: D
options.text: They have a higher risk of contracting only minor diseases

multiple-choice.question: What type of articles can be picked up by outlets not in on the joke and contribute to circular reporting?
How many times has a joke article in the British Medical Journal been referenced in serious science publications?
What is a common contributor to circular reporting?
What can make it harder to debunk an unverified fact in a wiki page?

options.label: A
options.text: When it is removed from the wiki page

options.label: B
options.text: When it is not cited in any published articles

options.label: C
options.text: When it is cited in a published article that is later added as a citation for the wiki information

options.label: D
options.text: When it is only viewed by a few people

multiple-choice.question: What can help slow down the spread of misinformation?

options.label: A
options.text: Searching for criticisms of suspicious information

options.label: C
options.text: Tracing the original source of a report

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential result of people's desire for quick answers overpowering their desire to be certain of the validity of information?

options.label: A
options.text: More accurate information will be spread

options.label: B
options.text: More people will verify information before sharing it

options.label: C
options.text: More caution is needed to avoid spreading misinformation

options.label: D
options.text: There will be no impact on the spread of information
